SP: natural sepiolite; SP-2: sepiolite activated with 2.0mol/L HCl aqueous solution. Hydrochloric acid activation was carried out at the temperature of 80°C with a solid/liquid ratio of 1:10 (mass/volume). TG analysis of the samples were carried out with a heating rate of 10°C/min from 30°C to 800°C in an air flow rate of 20ml/min. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The pore size distribution of a natural sepiolite sample (SP) and acid-activated catalyst samples (SP-2, SP-5 and SP-8). Hydrochloric acid activation was carried out at 80°C with a solid/liquid ratio of 1:10 (mass/volume). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of natural sepiolite samples and a series of acid-activated catalyst samples. S=sepiolite, T=talc, Q=quarz. The catalyst samples were denoted as SP-X, where “X” represents the concentration of hydrochloric acid used (mol/L). Graphical abstract In the search for novel solid acid catalysts for the gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein, sepiolite clay minerals were activated with hydrochloric acid to produce acid-activated sepiolite catalysts. The effects of the activation process on the texture and acidity of acid-activated sepiolite, and their roles in gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein, were then investigated. A series of acid-activated sepiolite catalysts were made from purified natural sepiolite treated with hydrochloric acid of different concentrations (0–8mol/L) at 80°C, followed by drying at 100°C. The acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction, X-ray fluorescence analysis, scanning electronic microscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, NH3-temperature-programmed desorption. Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy and pyridine adsorption followed by in situ infrared spectroscopy. The catalytic performances in gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein were studied using a vertical fixed-bed reactor. Typically, a glycerol conversion of 92.9%, an acrolein selectivity of 59.4%, and a yield of acrolein of 55.2% were achieved when the gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol was conducted over HCl (2mol/L) acid-activated sepiolite catalyst at 320°C with an aqueous glycerol solution (20wt.%) at a rate of 0.10ml/min as the feedstock and air as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 20ml/min. The activation of the sepiolite with hydrochloric acid followed by drying can eliminate a portion of the zeolitic water in the tunnels, remove part of the magnesium and aluminum cations in the octahedral sheets of sepiolite, unbundle aggregated sepiolite fibers, and partly break the Si-O-Si in the tetrahedral sheets of sepiolite. These factors increased the porosity, the specific surface area and the acidity of the sepiolite. The partial leaching of magnesium and aluminum ions in the octahedral sheet generated octahedral vacancies and created MgOAl+ sites in the octahedral sheets, thereby increasing the amount of Lewis acid sites. Along with penetration of H+ cations into the interlayered space of the sepiolite by an ion-exchange reaction and physicochemical surface adsorption, some breakage of the SiOSi bonds in the tetrahedral sheets generated more SiOH+, thus increasing the quantity of Brønsted acid sites. Furthermore, the strength of acidity of the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite was significantly changed after the acid activation. The medium-strong Brønsted acid sites (SiOH+ and H+ adsorbed on the surface) appeared to be beneficial for the high conversion of glycerol and the selectivity to acrolein. Lewis acid sites could facilitate the formation of acetol. Under the reaction conditions mentioned above, the coking on the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts readily occurred, rapidly leading to the decrease of the yield of acrolein. Keywords Glycerol Acrolein Sepiolite Clay mineral Acidity Coking 1 Introduction Glycerol is an unavoidable by-product from the industrial soap-making processes [1], the transesterification of fatty oil with alcohol to biofuel [2], and the production of fatty acids [1]. It can also be produced from microbial fermentation of cellulose and glucose [3]. Glycerol is now considered a platform chemical to produce value-added chemicals, polymers and fuel additives [4–6]. Catalytic dehydration of glycerol produces acrolein, which is used to produce acrylic acid, methionine, 1,3-propanediol, glutaraldehyde, and pyridine [7–10]. The catalytic dehydration of glycerol is a typical acid-catalyzed reaction. Namely, it usually needs to be conducted over homogeneous or heterogeneous acid catalysts. Homogeneous catalytic liquid-phase dehydration of glycerol with liquid acid as catalysts, for example sulfuric acid and hydrochloric acid, causes equipment corrosion, catalyst separation, and leads to waste management challenges [11]. Comparatively, the heterogeneous catalytic gas-phase dehydration of glycerol over solid acid catalysts can substantially avoid these concerns. The acidity and texture of solid acid catalysts are crucial factors in the catalytic dehydration of glycerol [4–6]. For example, Chai et al. [12] found that the strong Brønsted acid of solid acid catalysts appeared to be beneficial for a high yield of acrolein. A glycerol conversion of 70% and an acrolein selectivity of 60–70% were obtained at 315°C over WO3/ZrO2 and H3PW12O40/α-Al2O3 catalysts with H0 between −8.2 and −3.0. Moreover, the detailed investigation into the type of acidity suggested that the catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein should proceed via the protonation of the secondary hydroxyl group over Brønsted acid sites, then forming 3-hydroxypropanal with the elimination of a water molecule. It subsequently undergoes a second dehydration step, thereby leading to the formation of acrolein [13]. Alhanash et al. [14] used Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 with strong Brønsted acidity as a solid catalyst for the catalytic gas-phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. At 275°C, the conversion of glycerol was 100% and the selectivity of acrolein was ca. 98% after 1h. Nevertheless, the strong Brønsted acid sites caused severe coke deposition and hence rapidly decreased the activity of the catalyst. In addition to the acidity, the texture and porosity of the solid acid catalyst affects the mass transfer, selectivity, and coke formation during glycerol dehydration. Many studies indicated that acidic aluminosilicate zeolite catalysts, with a microporous structure, have transport limitations, which adversely affect catalytic performances of the catalyst, particularly when bulky molecules are involved. In view of this limitation, Decolatti et al. [15] treated zeolitic material H-ZSM5 with an aqueous sodium hydroxide solution to enhance the porosity for the catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. Such a treatment of H-ZSM-5 with an aqueous sodium hydroxide solution led to the development of mesopores and accordingly increased its porosity and specific surface area. Over the meso-microporous H-ZSM5 catalyst, the conversion of glycerol was 77.6% and the selectivity of acrolein was 58.6% after 5h. In our previous work, Zhao and Zhou et al. [16] treated montmorillonite clay minerals with acid and used acid-activated montmorillonite as a solid acid catalyst for the catalytic dehydration of glycerol. As a result, the acid-activated montmorillonite catalyst possessed high mesoporosity. The mesoporosity and H+ in the interlayer space were ascribed to the catalytic dehydration of glycerol. The findings implied that the conversion of glycerol and selectivity of acrolein could be further improved by finely tuning both texture and acidity of clay minerals. Compared with layered montmorillonite clay mineral, sepiolite (Si12O30Mg8(OH)4(OH2)4·8H2O, it is possible that Mg is partly replaced by Al) possesses additional exposed tunnel-like structures (openings) on the outer surface, additional to channels (pores) in the structure [17–26]. Such a structure allows sepiolite to have surface acidity and to be used as a solid acid catalyst. For example, sepiolite-based catalysts have been used in catalytic dehydration of 1-phenylethanol [17], transesterification of oil to biodiesel [18] and Suzuki reaction [19]. In particular, it is worth nothing that the discontinuous octahedral sheets of sepiolite provide available open tunnels (10.6Å in width) with the edges of broken bonds at either side. (Fig. 1 (A), (B)) [21,22]. In consideration of the catalytic dehydration of glycerol, such open tunnels are far larger than the size of a glycerol molecule (ca. 6.2Å) and the acidic sites on the tunnel surface are readily approachable for glycerol reactants. Specifically, both the silanol groups (SiOH+) at the edges of the tetrahedral sheets and the unsaturated Al3+ ions in the octahedral sheets are exposed, as are active acid sites [23]. The amount and type of such acid sites can be increased if more tunnels, edges and broken bonds are created by proper acidic activation [24], primarily because the acid activation of sepiolite under judiciously-chosen conditions can remove the zeolitic water and partly dissolve the layer framework of sepiolite. This enhances both the porosity and the specific surface area, and changes the type and strength of acidity [24,25]. To our knowledge, the effects of acid activation of sepiolite on the texture and acidity of sepiolite has not been investigated as much as that for montmorillonite. It has not yet been touched that acid-activated sepiolite catalysts act as catalysts for the catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. In the present work, we attempt to investigate the effects of texture and acidity of hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts and coke deposit on the performances of the acid-activated sepiolite catalysts in the catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. To this end, sepiolite was treated with hydrochloric acid of different concentrations to yield a series of hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts. The resultant hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples were then characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray fluorescence (XRF), scanning electronic microscopy (SEM), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), N2 adsorption-desorption, NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, and pyridine adsorption followed by in situ infrared spectroscopy. The performances of the acid-activated sepiolite catalysts were evaluated in the catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. Moreover, the state of coke formation on the catalysts and its effects on the deactivation of the catalysts were preliminarily investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Purified natural sepiolite was obtained from a Sepiolite Co., Ltd, Xiangtan, China. Hydrochloric acid activation was carried out using an aqueous HCl solution and distilled water; concentrations varied from 0.5mol/L to 8mol. For each activation reaction, a mixture at a solid sepiolite/liquid (aqueous HCl solution) ratio of 1:10 (mass/volume) was used. The slurry was stirred magnetically for 4h at 80°C, and after cooling down to room temperature, the suspensions were centrifuged and filtered, the collected solid was washed several times with distilled water until the filtrates were neutral. The as-obtained hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite samples were then dried at 100°C for 48h. The dried solids were crushed and sieved to obtain a uniform particle with a size of 40–60mesh (0.250–0.425mm). The catalyst samples were denoted as SP-X, where “X” represents the concentration of hydrochloric acid used (mol/L). The concentration of the aqueous hydrochloric acid solution is 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.5, 3.0, 3.5, 4.0, 4.5, 5.0, 6.0, 7.0 and 8.0mol/L, respectively. For investigating the possible influence of diffusion, SP-2 catalysts were also sieved between 20 and 40mesh (0.425–0.840mm), and 60–80mesh (0.180–0.250mm). 2.2 Catalytic reaction The dehydration of glycerol was carried out in a vertical fixed-bed quartz reactor (8mm i.d.) under atmospheric pressure. All reactions were operated at atmospheric pressure. For each run, 0.2g of catalyst was loaded into the constant temperature area of the reactor; quartz beads and silica wool were located and beneath the catalyst bed. Air as the carrier gas was used at a flow rate of 20ml/min. Prior to pumping the glycerol into the reactor, the catalyst bed was heated at an incremental rate of 10°C/min in a flow of air (20ml/min) to reach 320°C and kept for 3h. 15wt.% aqueous glycerol solution was then fed into the reactor at a flow rate of 0.10mlmin−1 with the above-mentioned carrier gas by a Kontron Instruments 422 HPLC pump. The reaction was carried out at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of glycerol of 4200h−1. The products and unconverted glycerol were collected hourly in an ice trap (0°C). The analysis was conducted using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with an FID and an HP-FFAP capillary column (0.32mm×30m). The column was held at 40°C for 4min before raising the temperature from 40 to 100°C at a rate of 10°C/min; the temperature was then increased from 100 to 190°C at a rate of 20°C/min, and maintained for 15min. Glycerol conversion, product selectivity, and product yields were calculated using the following Eqs. (1)–(3). (1) Glycerol conversion ( % ; X g l y ) = Moles of glycerol ( g l y ) reacted Moles of glycerol fed into the reactor × 100 % (2) Product selectivity ( % ; S p i ) = Moles of glycerol converted to a specific product ( p i ) Moles of glycerol reacted × 100 % (3) Product yield ( % ; Y p i ) = Moles of glycerol converted to a specific product ( p i ) Moles of glycerol fed into the reactor × 100 % 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal structure of natural and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts was analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Thermo ARL SCINTAG X'TRA diffractometer (CuKα, λ=1.54056Å, 40kV, 30mA, scan speed of 0.1°/s) in the 2θ range of 2–40°. The chemical composition of natural and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite samples was analyzed using an X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) from ARL ADVANT'X, IntelliPower TM 4200, Thermofisher. Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet AVATAR-370 spectrometer. The natural and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite samples dried at 110°C were mixed with KBr and then pressed into a wafer. The spectra were collected over the range 4000–400cm−1 by obtaining the average of 32 scans at a resolution of 4cm−1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of natural and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite samples were carried out on a Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC 1/1100 LF under a heating rate of 10°C/min from 30°C to 800°C in air at a flow rate of 20ml/min. The morphology of the natural and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite was analyzed using a Hitachi-4700 scanning electron microscope. The samples were coated with platinum and placed onto the Al sample stud before observation. The specific surface area and the pore volume of natural and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite samples were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption at 77K on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 instrument. Prior to adsorption, the samples were degassed at 300°C for 6h. The specific surface area was calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) theory [27]. The pore size distribution (suitable for mesopores) was calculated using the model of Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) [28]. NH3-temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted on a Finetec Finesorb-3010. Before each measurement, the sample (∼0.1g) was thermally treated at 300°C for 4h in helium at a flow rate of 30ml/min. After cooling down to ambient temperature, the sample was exposed to a mixing flow (30ml/min) with NH3 (10%) and helium for 0.5h and subsequently, purged with helium (27ml/min) for another 0.5h. After that, the sample was heated in the temperature range from 50°C to 800°C in helium (27ml/min) and the desorption of ammonia in the effluent stream was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The Brønsted and Lewis acid sites were determined by in situ FT-IR spectral analysis after pyridine adsorption. Each sepiolite sample was dried in an air oven for 2h and degassed at 350°C under vacuum (10−5 Torr) prior to the adsorption of pyridine. The adsorption of pyridine (10Torr) was performed at room temperature. In order to remove reversibly adsorbed pyridine molecules on the surface of the sample and to probe the strength of the surface acidity, the sample was then evacuated for 20min at 70°C, 150°C, and 350°C to desorb pyridine. The FT-IR measurements were conducted with a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. Each spectrum was recorded with the accumulation of 64 scans and a resolution of 4cm−1. Measurements of catalyst acidity (acid strength and amount) were based on the n-butylamine titration method using various Hammett indicators, including anthraquinone (p Ka=−8.2), dicinnamalacetone (p Ka=−3.0), neutral red (p Ka=+6.8), and p-Dimethylaminoazobenzene (p Ka=+3.3) and the experiments were conducted according to the methods in the literature [26]. Acid strength was expressed by Hammett acidity function (H 0) that was scaled by p Ka values of the indicators. 3 Results 3.1 Activity measurement The products of catalytic dehydration of glycerol over purified natural sepiolite catalyst and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts were acrolein, acetaldehyde, glycerolformal, acetol, acetic acid, propenol, and acrylic acid. When the natural sepiolite catalyst was used in catalytic dehydration of glycerol, conversion of glycerol was 73.9%, the selectivity of acrolein was 23.7%, and the selectivity of acetol was 6.9% (Table 1 ). Both the conversion of glycerol and the selectivity of acrolein increased over hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite. Comparatively, sepiolite activated by 2mol/L HCl (SP-2) exhibited the best catalytic performance. The conversion of glycerol was 92.9% and the selectivity of acrolein was 59.4%. The yield of acrolein reached 55.2%. However, as the concentration of the hydrochloric acid treated on sepiolite increased from 2.0mol/L to 8.0mol/L, the selectivity of acrolein decreased gradually from 59.4% to 28.8%, and the conversion of glycerol decreased gradually from 92.9% to 77.8%. Over the SP-8 catalysts, the yield of acrolein was merely 22.4%, less than half of that over the SP-2 catalysts (55.2%). In addition, over the series of catalysts, remarkable changes were observed for acetaldehyde and glycerolformal. A small amount of acrylic acid and propanol were produced and the yield of acetol varied only slightly. Assuming that the texture and acidity influenced catalytic activity and selectivity, it was reasonably believed here that the texture and acidity of sepiolite have been significantly tuned by the activation process. Moreover, the texture and acidity of these sepiolite catalysts depended heavily upon the conditions used for the activation. In order to check the possible effects of diffusion, the catalytic activities over a series of the SP-2 catalysts with different particle sizes were measured (Table 1). In general, provided that there are diffusional limitations, the catalyst size will significantly influence the reaction. The smaller the particle is, the less time is required for the reactants to move to the active acid sites and for the products to diffuse out of the particle. However, such influence can be avoided by judiciously-chosen particle size. Under the conditions used in this work, the catalytic activities of the SP-2 catalyst were not remarkably affected by diffusion. Namely, the effect of mass transfer appeared to be negligible and diffusion limitations contributed little to the catalytic activities. Hence the surface adsorption and reactions relevant to the texture and acidity were thought to be critical to the catalytic performances. Accordingly, the characterization of the texture of the catalysts and the measurements of the number and the type of the acid sites on the catalysts can provide insights into the exact relationship between catalyst surface (structure and active sites) and catalytic performances, 3.2 Effect of texture of catalyst The typical sepiolite fibers in the form of agglomerated dense bundles of sepiolite catalysts were clearly observed on SEM images (Fig. 2 ). Compared with a natural sepiolite sample, the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite sample showed disaggregated fibers to some degree. By contrast, samples activated with hydrochloric acid (2.0mol/L and 8.0mol/L), namely the SP-2 and the SP-8 samples, exhibited fiber shapes more clearly (Fig. 2(B), (C)). The sepiolite bundled crystalline fibers were unbundled, or unfolded, as a result of acid treatment. The extent related to the concentration of the aqueous hydrochloric acid solution used. The length of natural sepiolite was about 1.2μm (Fig. 2(A)), and it decreased to 0.8–1.0μm after hydrochloric acid activation (Fig. 2(B) and (C)). When an aqueous 8.0mol/L hydrochloric acid solution was used for the treatment, the resultant SP-8 revealed a severe breakage of sepiolite fibers, leading to the formation of much shorter fibers and even many particle-like solids (<0.3μm) (Fig. 2D). Natural sepiolite is phyllosilicate rich in Si, Mg and Al [29]. The chemical composition of natural sepiolite expressed in the form of oxide as a percentage were: 53.3% SiO2, 21.9% MgO, 13.2% Al2O3, 5.0% P2O5, 2.7% Fe2O3, 1.4% CaO and 1.2% Na2O (Table 2 ). When sepiolite was activated by 2.0mol/L HCl, the elemental analysis showed that there were changes of the contents of Si, Mg, Al, Ca and Na. Expressed in the form of oxide as a percentage, the contents of major elements in the framework of hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite samples (SP-2) was as follows: SiO2 increased to 74.2%, MgO decreased to 14.2%, and Al2O3 decreased to 9.0%. Clearly, the Al and Mg cations were to some extent removed. Sepiolite generally contains three kinds of water: the superficially adsorbed water, the zeolitic water, and the structural water. The second one includes water molecules, which are usually believed present in the interlayer space of sepiolite in hydrated cations. The last one might exist in the form of OH in the framework, namely tetrahedral and octahedral sheets of sepiolite. The three types of water were eliminated usually in the same order as the increasing temperature [30–33]. Thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 3 .) revealed that there are three stages of mass loss for the natural sepiolite and the acid-activated sepiolite during heating from 30 to 800°C. For the SP sample, superficially adsorbed water took up about 8.8% and the zeolitic water took up 6.9%. By contrast, for the SP-2 sample, the percentage of the two type of water was 7.1% and 4.6%, respectively. Activation of sepiolite with hydrochloric acid remarkably reduced the amount of zeolitic water. Considering the SP-2 sample was activated in hydrochloric acid at 80°C and dried at 100°C, it was thought reasonably that such treatment predominantly changed the amount of zeolitic water. For the two samples, there is much difference in mass loss of the structural water, which can only be removed at higher temperature (>600–700°C). Only at very high temperatures did dihydroxylation of the framework occur with the possible phase change from sepiolite to clinoenstatite [32] or other amorphous silicate, magnesia and alumina and the related compounds [33]. The specific surface area of natural sepiolite (SP) was 33m2/g (Table 3 ). The specific surface areas of hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts increased to 198m2/g (SP-2), 176m2/g (SP-5), and 162m2/g (SP-8). The high specific surface areas meant that more surfaces were exposed leading to the higher conversion of glycerol and the increased selectivity of acrolein (Table 1). In addition, more meso- to macropores (ca. 30–70nm) appeared on hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples (SP-2, SP-5 and SP-8) (Fig. 4 ). Clearly, hydrochloric acid removed the impurities and zeolite water in the tunnels as well as unbundled the aggregates of sepiolite fibers. All this led to more open space in the resultant acid-activated sepiolite catalysts. The pore volume and average pore diameter of natural sepiolite was ca. 0.36cm3/g and 30nm, respectively. The hydrochloric acid activation increased both the pore volume and the pore diameter of the sepiolite catalysts. The SP-2 sample mainly possessed pore diameters in the range of 30–55nmnm, as indicated by the BJH (dV/dlogD) pore size distribution (Fig. 4). Such BJH pore size distribution confirmed the much meso- to macroporosity of hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite. Nevertheless, it also showed a slightly broader distribution of pores. Clearly, when activated in hydrochloric acid with a higher concentration, the SP-8 sample showed an obvious difference from the SP-2 and the SP-5. The results confer with observations from SEM images (Fig. 2). It is common that the acid treatment of clay minerals changes the texture and porosity to a lesser or great extent, dependent upon the conditions used for the acid treatments [34]. It was worth noting that the pore sizes of the catalysts are far much larger than the sizes of glycerol molecules and the molecules of products. Thus there is no remarkable diffusional limitations (Tables 1 and 3). Powder XRD patterns of natural purified and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . The characteristic reflections of sepiolite were at 2 theta 3.72° (110), 9.90° (060), 10.40° (131), 11.90° (260), and 14.27° (331) [29] (JCPDS card 75–1597). The reflections at 4.71°and 13.32° were ascribed to minor impurities (talc (002) and quarz (080)). For the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts, the characteristic (110) reflection increasingly became broad and weak, compared with that of the natural sepiolite. Such trendency has a linear reastionship with the increase of the concentration of hydrochloric acid used for acid activation of sepiolite. When the hydrochloric acid concentration increased to 8.0mol/L (SP-8), the (110) reflection almost disappeared. The servere removal of Mg2+ and Al3+ in the octahedral sheet of sepiolite can disrupt the octahedral sheet and even the whole layers, thereby weakening the (110) reflection in the powder XRD [30]. 3.3 Effect of acidity of catalyst FT-IR spectra of the natural sepiolite catalyst samples and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 6 . The absorption at 3430cm−1 was attributed to the O—H stretching vibration of water molecules adsorbed on the surface of sepiolite. The absorptions at 3644cm−1 and 3558cm−1 were most possibly caused by the stretching vibration of the OH groups that are bonded with Mg2+ or Al3+ in the octahedral sheets and the OH bending vibration of Mg(Al)—OH [35]. The OSiO stretching occurred at 910cm−1 and the SiOSi asymmetric stretching occurred at 1210cm−1. Absorptions at 690cm−1 caused by the SiOSi stretching vibrations were also observed [36–38]. The Si-O stretching and asymmetric can be seen at 1075 and 1022cm−1. For hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples, the decrease of the intensity of the absorption bands in the range of 3430–3644cm−1 verified the removal of the water and even the OH groups. In particular, the latter was mostly due to the leaching of Mg2+ and Al3+ from the octahedral sheets of sepiolite [36]. Further, the absorptions at 690cm−1, and 520cm−1 were attributed to vibration induced by AlOH groups and the vibrations of AlOSi, and the decrease of absorbance at those regions also indicated certain release of the octahedral Al atoms from the structure of the sepiolite. The absorbance bands at 470cm−1, 800cm−1,1022cm−1, and 1210cm−1 resulted from the stretching of SiO groups in the SiOSi groups. Compared with the natural sepiolite catalyst sample, these bands of the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples grew stronger, possibly due to the formation of some amorphous silica [36,37]. When the acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples were produced from the activation process by the increased amount of hydrochloric acid, the absorbance band corresponding to OSiO shifted to a lower wavenumber. Such a shift suggested that there was some alteration in the tetrahedral sheet of sepiolite [39]. Pyridine adsorption followed by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy was conducted to distinguish the type of acidity on the surface of the natural sepiolite catalyst sample (SP) and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples (SP-2 and SP-5) (Fig. 7 (A), (B)). The transmittance was recorded in the region of 1400–1700cm−1. In the FT-IR spectra, the characteristic adsorption bands of pyridine on natural and hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts were detected at 1448cm−1, 1492cm−1, 1545cm−1, 1614cm−1 and 1623cm−1 (Fig. 7(A)). The absorption at ca. 1492cm−1 was assigned to both Brønsted and Lewis (B+L) acidic sites. A strong absorption band centered at 1448cm−1 exclusively suggested the presence of Lewis acid sites (C6H5N:Lδ+). The absorption at 1545cm−1 was characteristic of C6H5N:H+ and signified the presence of Brønsted acid sites. Comparatively, the intensity of absorptions at 1448cm−1 and 1545cm−1 of the SP-2 sample and the SP-5 sample appeared stronger than those of the SP sample. This meant that the amounts of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites increased for the hydrochloric acid-treated sepiolite samples. For the SP-2 sample, the strength of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites was obtained from pyridine adsorption-desorption at (a) 70°C, (b) 150°C, (c) 350°C and monitored by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. 7(B)). After heating at 150°C, the adsorption centered at 1448cm−1 decreased and the adsorption centered at 1543cm−1 showed little change. For the sample heated at 350°C, the adsorption centered at 1448cm−1 decreased and the adsorption centered at 1543cm−1 disappeared. Clearly, the Lewis acid sites were more stable than the Brønsted acid sites. NH3-temperature-programed desorption (NH3-TPD) was adopted to provide information on the amount and strength of acid sites (Fig. 7(C)). As shown in the NH3-TPD profiles, an intense peak between 500 and 700°C was found on the SP sample. Peaks between 80 and 100°C were all found for the SP-2 sample, the SP-5 sample and SP-8 sample. Exclusively, remarkable NH3 desorption at 280–380°C were merely found on the SP-2 sample. The peak between 80 and 100°C was ascribed to weak acid sites, the peak between 280 and 380°C was caused by medium to strong acid sites and the peak between 500 and 700°C was attributed to much stronger acid sites. It was found that such much stronger acidity of sepiolite disappeared and the strength of acidity changed to the strong, medium, and weak after activation by hydrochloric acid, owing to the change of the types and the amount of acidity. The quantification of the acid sites of different acid strengths of the catalysts by the n-butylamine titration showed that the SP-2 catalyst had distinctively less weak acid sites while it had more medium to strong acid sites (Table 4 ). The measurements were in good agreement with the determination by NH3-TPD (Fig. 7(C)). The number and type of the acid sites were thought to be the inherent factors for the peculiar catalytic performances of the SP-2 catalyst. 3.4 Coking Examination of coke deposits and their effect on hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst (SP-2) were investigated in the catalytic dehydration of glycerol under the following conditions: 320°C, GHSV=4200h−1, glycerol concentration=15wt.% pumped at 0.10ml/min, and the flow rate of air carrier gas=20ml/min. As other solid acid catalysts reported in the literature, the catalysts exhibited a good catalytic activity after an induction period of ca. 1h (Fig. 8 ). The catalyst remained active for another few hours. The conversion of glycerol reached around 80–93% and the selectivity to acrolein remained at 52–63% for 2h–5h, with a noticeable decline after 5h. The selectivity of acetol showed an inverse trend when compared to the selectivity to acrolein. The formation of acetol was thought to be closely related to Lewis acidic sites [5]. The detailed reason for this is unknown at the time of this study. It was observed a change in color to black from the original grey when spent catalysts were taken out from the reactor, indicating the occurrence of coking. As confirmed by TG-DTG analysis (Fig. 9 ), the presence of carbonaceous deposit can be burned at high temperatures, in particular at 360–800°C. In such a range, the mass loss of and the used (SP-2(8h)) catalyst sample was much greater than that of the fresh (SP-2) catalyst sample. The percentage of carbonaceous deposit on the used (SP-2(8h)) catalyst sample could reach around 13%. XRD, FT-IR spectroscopy and NH3-TPD analysis of the fresh (SP-2) catalyst sample and the used (SP-2(8h)) hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst sample were conduced to further investigate the reasons for the changes of performances of the catalysts during the reaction (Fig. 10 (A)). Regarding the spent hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst sample (SP-2(8h)), the reflection of (110) appeared weaker than that of the fresh hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst (SP-2) (Fig. 10(A)), suggesting that the coke was formed on the SP-2 catalyst. Moreover, as no chracteristic reflections of graphtic carbon were obseverd, the coke was believed to be amorphous carbon and in the form of a macromolecular complex [41]. The comparative examination by FT-IR spectroscopy for the fresh (SP-2) catalyst sample and the spent (SP-2(8h)) hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst sample showed that there was a great difference in the absorbance bands (Fig. 10(B)). Generally, for the SP-2(8h) sample, several absorbance bands, including those at 3644cm−1, 3558cm−1, 3430cm−1, and 1654cm−1 almost disappeared. These bands were mainly attributed to the vibrations induced by —OH groups in the sepiolite. The disappearance of these absorbance bands was reasonable because the catalyst was spent at 320°C for 8h and thus the surface adsorbed water of sepiolite and the zeolitic water inside the tunnels was removed further. Nevertheless, considering the maintenance of the absorbance bands in the fingerprint region (1330–400cm−1 usually), for example those at 1210cm−1, 1075cm−1, 1022cm−, 910cm−1, 690cm−1, 520cm−1 and 800cm−1, the basic structure of sepiolite remained intact, evidenced by the XRD patterns (Fig. 10(A)). This implied that the decrease of catalytic performance should not be ascribed to the structural change of the sepiolite. Instead, it was due to the fact that the loss of the surface adsorbed water on the sepiolite and the zeolitic water inside the tunnels of the sepiolite and the coking led to a remarkable change of surface acidity, as detected by NH3-TPD analysis (Fig. 10(C)). The used sepiolite catalyst (SP-2 (8h)) has both the weak and medium strong acid sites. Compared with the fresh catalyst (SP-2), the TPD peak of the used catalyst related to the medium acid site shifted to higher temperatures, namely from 325 to 425°C, and the peak related to the weak acid site shifted from 80 to 100°C. A possible explanation was due to the continuous heating for 8h under reaction conditions for the catalytic dehydration of glycerol. But the acidic sites, in particular those with medium strength, mostly remain. As a consequence, the catalysts maintained remarkable catalytic activity, but the selectivity to acrolein rapidly decreased to 20% (Fig. 8). 4 Discussion Compared with the natural sepiolite catalyst, the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts all exhibited increased catalytic activity (Table 1). Typically, over the SP-2 catalyst, the conversion of glycerol and the selectivity to acrolein increased roughly by 20% and 36%, respectively, compared to the SP catalyst. Because the catalytic dehydration of glycerol proved to be an acid-catalyzed reaction [6,42,43], here the results clearly indicated that acid treatment of sepiolite significantly enhanced the acidity of the sepiolite. However, such a change did not show a linear increase with the increase of the acid concentration used for the treatment of the sepiolite. The data therefore suggested that the acid treatment of sepiolite de facto was a much more complex process, although the activation reaction is seemingly simple in following form: an ion-exchange reaction of cation M+ in the tunnels and channel of sepiolite with H+ in the aqueous acid solution; partly or complete breakage of framework of the sepiolite. These reactions have been well-documented for clay mineral-based catalysts [44,45]. For the catalytic dehydration of glycerol, a mechanistic study suggested that the type, the amount, and the strength of the acidity can all exert more or less influence on the catalytic activity and the selectivity [43]. As showed in Table 1, before and after the acid treatment, the sepiolite catalysts resulted in varying selectivity to acrolein. The porosity and specific surface areas of the catalysts varied with conditions used for the acid treatments (Table 3). It is noteworthy however that selectivity is not only determined by the porosity of a catalysts but also influenced by the type, amount, and the strength of the acidity of the catalysts, primarily because these chemical factors play a pivotal role in the primary and secondary or any other subsequent reactions [47]. As a result, the selectivity and the yield of acrolein appeared to vary over various sepiolite catalysts made from aqueous hydrochloric acid solution of different concentrations. It is noteworthy that, as opposed to frequently-used activated montmorillonite, for example sepiolite, the acid treatment had an additional role in increasing the available catalytic acidic sites by so-called unbundling process to form an unfolded structure [48]. As observed in the SEM images (Fig. 2), the extent of the unbundling has a close relationship with the concentration of an aqueous hydrochloric acid solution used for the acid activation processes. Considering that the unbundling substantially contributed to the exposure of tunnels, revealing more available surfaces with active acidic sites for glycerol reactants, the effects of the acid treatment were indeed more sophisticated. Appropriate acidity and texture, which can be altered by the acid activation process, provide both general and superficial reasons as to why the sepiolite activated by 2mol/L (SP-2) performs better (Tables 1 and 4). The roles of acid treatment in the change of texture, in particular the alteration of the porosity, were proved by the data from the analyses of N2 adsorption-desorption (Tables 3 and 4). Moreover, TEM images (Fig. 2) and XRD patterns (Fig. 5) clearly suggested that the acid treatment not only remove trace impurities from the purified sepiolite materials, but also cleaned the tunnels and channels of the sepiolite crystals, hence generating more openings and space in the resultant catalysts. Usually, mild to strong acid treatment can remove part of Mg and Al in the octahedral sheets of sepiolite. Comparatively, the Si in the tetrahedral sheets of sepiolite are more difficult to remove. The findings in this work were in accordance with earlier reports in the literature [49,50]. For the SP-2 sample, elemental contents of Mg and Al decreased remarkably (Table 2). This clearly implied that for the SP-2 sample, Mg and Al in the octahedral sheets of sepiolite were partly removed but the layered structure of the sepiolite and the basic fibrous morphology remained, rather than collapsing or sustaining severe damage. In addition to the texture, the significant influence of the acid treatment on the surface acidity of the sepiolite were evidenced by the changes in the chemical composition, FTIR spectra, pyridine adsorption followed by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy and NH3-TPD analysis for the samples before and after acid activation (Table 2 and Fig. 6–7). According to the elemental analysis (Table 2), for the SP-2 sample the amounts of Ca2+ and Na+, which commonly exist in the interlayer space as hydrated exchangeable cations [46], fell remarkably, compared with the pristine sepiolite SP sample. This can be ascribed to the occurrence of a cation exchange reaction between the Ca2+ and Na+ cations and H+ cations. In addition, hydrochloric acid activation altered the acidity through reducing the total water content of the SP-2 by 1) the dehydration of interlayered cations (Fig. 3), 2) proton (H+) penetration into the sepiolite structure, and 3) decreasing the zeolitic water and by part removal of the Mg2+ and Al3+ in the octahedral sheets [44,45,48,51]. As a result, the acid activation process created more Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites [52–55]. Moreover, Lewis acid sites were more stable than the Brønsted acid sites, particularly under the conditions for the catalytic glycerol dehydration at 320°C. Based on the examination and discussion above, the roles of hydrochloric acid activation in tuning the texture and acidity and the relevant influence on the catalytic dehydration of glycerol are postulated (Scheme 1 ). Naturally, the surface acidic sites existed in natural sepiolite, such as SiOH+ in the tetrahedral sheets, and a few MgOAl+ sites in the octahedral sheets, namely Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites, respectively [40,54,55]. After activation by hydrochloric acid, the magnesium and aluminum in the octahedral sheets of sepiolite were partly removed, leading to a slight increase of MgOAl+ sites and some vacancy in the octahedral sheets (SP-2) [44,55]. These MgOAl+ acted as Lewis acid sites and are usually considered responsible for the formation acetol. There were only slight changes in the amount of Lewis acid sites, and therefore, the selectivity to acetol did not alter significantly over the series of catalysts (Table 1). By contrast, the amount of SiOH+ at the edges of channels of sepiolite predominantly increased due to the unbundling of aggregated fibrous sepiolite crystallites [48], certain breakage of SiOSi to form SiOH+ [43,49,55], and H+ intercalated in the interlayer space or physicochemically adsorbed on the surface. All these Brønsted acid H+ could acted as weak to medium Brønsted acid sites (Scheme 1A). Simultaneously, Mg(Al)OH+ at the edges of the sepiolite structure will also be additionally formed due to the acid treatment [52–54]. Nevertheless, the Mg(Al)OH+ at the edges of sepiolite can be weak Brønsted acid sites. Under mild acid activation, the number of such acid sites was minimal. In addition, the Mg—O—Al+ in octahedral sheets were found as weak Lewis acid site [54,55]. In this work, the highest yield of acrolein (55.2%) was obtained over the SP-2 catalyst (Table 1), on which there are distinctly more medium to strong Brønsted acid sites and less weak acid sites (Fig. 7C and Table 4) compared with other acid-activated samples (SP-0, SP-5 and SP-8). In this aspect, the medium Brønsted acid site (mainly, SiOH+ and adsorbed H+ on the surface) were thus believed to be beneficial for the high yield of acrolein (Scheme 1B) [43]. It is possible that when attacked by active Brønsted acid H+, the molecules of glycerol were catalytically dehydrated first, leading to 3-hydroxypropanal. The 3-hydroxypropanal was then further attacked by active free Brønsted acid H+ to undergo a second dehydration to form acrolein [4–6,43]. Lewis acid sites had a tendency to catalyze the formation of acetol by glycerol dehydration [5]. Because the Lewis acid sites were located in the octahedral sheets, they were much difficultly contacted by glycerol molecules. Thus the selectivity to acetol appeared much lower and varied little over all the catalysts. In addition to arcolein, acetaldehyde and glycerolformal also varied remarkably over the various catalysts. It can be preliminarily deduced that these products were also produced through Brønsted acid catalysis. Only when surface acidity exists (Figs. 8 and 10) can the catalysts keep remarkable catalytic activity, as reflected by glycerol conversion. But during the catalytic glycerol dehydration reaction, the coke was readily formed and deposited onto the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalyst. This led to a rapid decrease of the selectivity and yield of acrolein. The decrease of the yield of acrolein was caused inherently by the side reactions such as polymerization of acrolein and its precursor hydroxypropanal and eventual carbonization to coking at 320°C [5,47]. In particular, acid catalysts can catalyze these reactions. To obtain any more detail, further systematic investigation is needed, which was not within this scope of the present initial study on the roles of texture and acidity of acid-activated sepiolite in gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. 5 Conclusion Hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite clay minerals have proved to be a class of active solid acid catalyst for the gas-phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein. A 92.9% conversion of glycerol, a 59.4% selectivity of acrolein, and a 55.2% yield of acrolein were obtained over the sepiolite catalyst activated with a 2mol/L HCl aqueous solution when the catalytic dehydration of glycerol was conducted in a fixed-bed reactor at 320°C with a feed of 15wt.% aqueous glycerol solution at 0.10ml/min and air at a flow rate of 20ml/min. Both the texture and the acidity of sepiolite could be altered by the process of hydrochloric acid activation. The activation had several effects, including elimination of a portion of the zeolitic water in the tunnels, part of removal of magnesium and aluminum in the octahedral sheets of sepiolite, and the unbundling or unfolding of aggregated sepiolite fibers and even some breakage of the Si-O-Si in the tetrahedral sheets of sepiolite. The extent related to the concentration of hydrochloric acid used for activation. These factors changed the porosity the specific surface area. The part removal of magnesium and aluminum formed more Lewis acid sites. The elimination of surface adsorbed water and zeolitic water, and H+ intercalation into the interlayered space or adsorbed in the on the surface, generated significantly more Brønsted acid sites. The increased amount of SiOH+ and Mg(Al)OH+ groups at the edges of the sepiolite tunnels and channels also contributed to increasing the number of Brønsted acid sites. In addition to the type and the amount, the strength of the acid sites on the sepiolite catalysts could also able be tuned by acid activation. Acidity was found to play a crucial role in the conversion of glycerol and the selectivity to acrolein. The medium to strong Brønsted acid sites from SiOH+ and H+ adsorbed on the surface were responsible for yielding acrolein. Lewis acid sites could primarily catalyze the formation of acetol. The coking readily occurred on the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite during the catalytic dehydration of glycerol in the reactor. Nevertheless, if acid sites on the surface of the catalysts were available to glycerol molecules, catalytic activity remained, but the selectivity and the yield of acrolein fell rapidly. The findings revealed that for acid-catalyzed glycerol dehydration over acid-activated sepiolite catalysts, future work should focus on overcoming acid-catalyzed polymerization of acrolein and other intermediate molecules and their further carbonization. coredata.dc:description: In the search for novel solid acid catalysts for the gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein, sepiolite clay minerals were activated with hydrochloric acid to produce acid-activated sepiolite catalysts. The effects of the activation process on the texture and acidity of acid-activated sepiolite, and their roles in gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein, were then investigated. A series of acid-activated sepiolite catalysts were made from purified natural sepiolite treated with hydrochloric acid of different concentrations (0–8mol/L) at 80°C, followed by drying at 100°C. The acid-activated sepiolite catalyst samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction, X-ray fluorescence analysis, scanning electronic microscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, NH3-temperature-programmed desorption. Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy and pyridine adsorption followed by in situ infrared spectroscopy. The catalytic performances in gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol to acrolein were studied using a vertical fixed-bed reactor. Typically, a glycerol conversion of 92.9%, an acrolein selectivity of 59.4%, and a yield of acrolein of 55.2% were achieved when the gas-phase catalytic dehydration of glycerol was conducted over HCl (2mol/L) acid-activated sepiolite catalyst at 320°C with an aqueous glycerol solution (20wt.%) at a rate of 0.10ml/min as the feedstock and air as the carrier gas at a flow rate of 20ml/min. The activation of the sepiolite with hydrochloric acid followed by drying can eliminate a portion of the zeolitic water in the tunnels, remove part of the magnesium and aluminum cations in the octahedral sheets of sepiolite, unbundle aggregated sepiolite fibers, and partly break the Si-O-Si in the tetrahedral sheets of sepiolite. These factors increased the porosity, the specific surface area and the acidity of the sepiolite. The partial leaching of magnesium and aluminum ions in the octahedral sheet generated octahedral vacancies and created MgOAl+ sites in the octahedral sheets, thereby increasing the amount of Lewis acid sites. Along with penetration of H+ cations into the interlayered space of the sepiolite by an ion-exchange reaction and physicochemical surface adsorption, some breakage of the SiOSi bonds in the tetrahedral sheets generated more SiOH+, thus increasing the quantity of Brønsted acid sites. Furthermore, the strength of acidity of the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite was significantly changed after the acid activation. The medium-strong Brønsted acid sites (SiOH+ and H+ adsorbed on the surface) appeared to be beneficial for the high conversion of glycerol and the selectivity to acrolein. Lewis acid sites could facilitate the formation of acetol. Under the reaction conditions mentioned above, the coking on the hydrochloric acid-activated sepiolite catalysts readily occurred, rapidly leading to the decrease of the yield of acrolein.
